The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are critical for induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the cargo-receptor complex. We also show that a single amino acid substitution in Orf6 abolishes its ability to block nuclear import and impair IFN antagonism. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 evades the antiviral action of IFN and may provide a target for the development of antiviral strategies. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms of how the NPC is hijacked by pathogens to impair antiviral signaling. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, and the magnitude of the effects depends on the rate of warming. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of plant material is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity of large mammals may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of African savanna. (Show more)

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous problem in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly because of size-selective sinks. These sinks are likely to be related to the nano-fragmentation of plastic debris, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered.

The origin of the Solar System is one of the most important unsolved problems in astronomy. The Cosmic Ray Exposure Ages of interstellar grains from the Murchison meteorite provide constraints on the age of the Solar System and the formation of the Sun. We determined ages of 40 interstellar grains from the Murchison meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. These results provide constraints on the formation of the Sun and the early Solar System. They also provide evidence for an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. This work provides a new perspective on the origin of the Solar System. It also provides a new perspective on the origin of the Solar System.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded dramatically. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotective effects in the nigrostriatal system. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This would be the first disease-modifying therapy for this orphan disease. This would also be the first example of a drug that is able to limit α-syn pathology in a synucleinopathy. This would have important implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for synucleinopathies.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modeling. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a rich set of data on COVID activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking COVID activity, and can be used to augment traditional public health reporting. The COVIDcast API is available at https://covidcast.org.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a deeper understanding of the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood, but they are likely important for maintaining the diversity of the microbiome. This study provides a comprehensive catalog of the natural products produced by anaerobic fungi, which could be used as a source of new bioactive compounds. The results suggest that anaerobic fungi are a promising source of natural products. This study also provides a resource for future studies on the role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders, and social anxiety is the most prevalent. However, the mechanisms underlying social anxiety remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety

The ability to design and fabricate multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. It can also be extended to other fields, such as soft robotics, where the ability to design and fabricate multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is highly desired.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway, which is known to affect the timing of development. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 mRNA-binding protein is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and that it is expressed in the fetal period and silenced in the adult period. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can mediate the reversal of the adult hemoglobin pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This is achieved by increased gamma-globin and decreased beta-globin expression, resulting in gamma-globin levels rising to 90% of total beta-like mRNA. This study provides evidence for a mechanism of chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. This may have important implications for the understanding of hemoglobinopathies and for the development of therapeutic strategies. It also provides a potential target for the development of therapeutic strategies for hemoglobinopathies. (Show more)

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and the transcriptional induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central regulator of lipid metabolism. Furthermore, we show that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Finally, we demonstrate that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and the most important risk factor for heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are associated with an increased risk of heart failure. We show that LCCBs act on the N terminus of the Ca2+ sensor STIM to cause STIM relocalization to junctions and ORAI activation in a Cav1.2-independent and store depletion-independent manner. LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study unravels a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings may help to explain the increased risk of heart failure associated with LCCBs and may lead to the development of new strategies for treating hypertension. This study also provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP’s policy of protecting older forests stabilized bird populations in the federal forests of Oregon and Washington. We found that bird populations tracked changes in forest composition, but the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings underscore the need to continue to protect older forests and to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings have implications for the conservation of biodiversity in the face of climate change.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be used to design new antibiotics for other antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations. The proposed architecture is easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This architecture can be applied to other problems in the future.

Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. This study shows that this technology use, in particular the use of light-emitting devices, has important implications for sleep. The results show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12,900 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the magnetic grains and microspherules collected from the YDB sites is consistent with a terrestrial origin. In contrast, the Os isotopic composition of bulk sediments from the YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggests a meteoritic origin of Os. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in different autoimmune diseases is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deficiency induced a spectrum of autoimmunity, which was not only more severe than congenital deficiency, but also affected both central and peripheral tolerance. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system and its relevance in autoimmunity. They also suggest that CTLA-4 deficiency may be a therapeutic strategy for autoimmune diseases. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system and its relevance in autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling specialized plant feeding, including the first independent origins of leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialized plant feeding was key to the Mesozoic diversification of beetles, and that the horizontal transfer of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls may have been key to the subsequent diversification of beetles. These findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of herbivory and the origin of insect diversity. (Show more)

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of currently available vaccines and treatments. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning algorithm to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We applied this algorithm to a human antibody, P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our algorithm identified CDR changes that improved the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work provides a promising approach for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We manipulated population size such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Our results indicate that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. This work provides a large-scale, large-sample replication of a classic experiment in the field of cultural evolution. It also provides a large-scale, large-sample replication of a classic experiment in the field of experimental economics. The results of this work have implications for the design of experiments in both fields.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is protective, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. APOE is also highly associated with astrocyte function, and APOE2 enhances astrocyte phagocytic capacity, whereas APOE4 decreases it. Here, we show that APOE isoform is highly associated with the rate of accumulation of complement component C1q-coated senescent synapses in the hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and they suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocyte phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies also provide a possible mechanism for the protective effect of APOE2 in AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,200 km in diameter and 15 km in radius. It is the densest material in the Earth, with a density of 12.04 g/cm3, which is 14 times that of water. The inner core is thought to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the Earth. It is expected to have a significant impact on the understanding of the Earth's interior. It also provides a new approach to understanding the formation of other dense materials.

Marijuana legalization debates highlight the need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]), which is a surrogate for probing the reactivity of the brain to DA stimulation. This blunted reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings suggest that chronic marijuana use may impair brain DA responses, which may contribute to addiction.

Language is the defining cognitive skill of the human species. Despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only poorly understood. Here, we show that deep learning models that predict well on a language understanding task also predict well on a brain imaging study of language comprehension. This suggests that the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are tuned to predict the next word in a sequence. Our results provide computational and neuroscientific support for a key hypothesis in the field: that language comprehension is fundamentally a predictive process. They also suggest that the brain may be using large language models to predict the next word in a sentence, and that this may help explain why these models are so good at language understanding.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability is not intrinsic to DL but rather a consequence of the difficulty of training deep neural networks. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a network. This result provides a classification theory of stability, which can be used to design algorithms for stable neural networks. We also introduce a new algorithm, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENET), which we prove to be stable and verify to be fast and stable. This paper is a step toward a better understanding of the limits of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. The classic experiment that is often cited as evidence for this phenomenon is discussed here. It is shown that the study’s design flaws were so severe that it cannot be used to support the conclusion that people are unable to understand exponential growth. The study’s conclusion is instead that people are unable to understand the implications of exponential growth.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico, where leprosy is endemic, and found that it contains a near-complete genome sequence of a new species, which we named Mycobacterium lepromatosis. We also sequenced the genome of M. leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and compared the two genomes. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause peripheral neuropathy, whereas M. leprae has lost the ability to infect Schwann cells. Our findings suggest that M. lepromatosis is a human pathogen that may be responsible for the new reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. Our findings also suggest that the two leprosy bacilli have retained many of their ancestral functions and are remarkably conserved despite their ancient separation. (Show more)

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the Heisenberg spin chain can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is a regime where the entanglement entropy is a good quantity to characterize the state of the system. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg spin chain and find perfect agreement. Our work provides a powerful tool to study the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are not 100% effective, and the pandemic is far from over. Therefore, the development of a highly effective, safe, and easy-to-administer vaccine is urgently needed. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is highly protective in a relevant hamster model. This vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, which is a desirable property for a vaccine strain. The vaccine is also easy to manufacture and can be stored at 2–8 °C, which is a major advantage over other vaccines. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. Therefore, it can play a major role in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. This study provides a promising vaccine candidate for the global pandemic. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were responsible for the spread of the disease. However, there is little evidence to support this hypothesis. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the best fit to mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1347–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model fitting, which allows for uncertainty in the model parameters. This approach is particularly important when studying historical epidemics, where there is often little evidence to support the model assumptions. Our results show that the model can be used to test hypotheses about the vector of plague, and that the model can be used to study the spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic. The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience for more than a century. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity, which is the ultimate goal of neuroscience, has been neglected. This study provides a comprehensive reconstruction of the evolution of brain information-processing capacity across amniotes, which is the most inclusive group of tetrapods. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results suggest that the evolution of brain size and neuronal density are not independent of each other and that the evolution of brain size is not a good proxy for the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human brain.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria has been controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and suggests that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin dynamics. It is involved in many cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cytokinesis. However, the molecular mechanism by which ADF regulates actin dynamics is still not fully understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF enhances severing of filaments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist. This ADF-induced torque dramatically enhances severing, which is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF enhances actin filament disassembly and may help to understand how ADF is regulated in cells. They also provide a general framework for understanding how mechanical forces can enhance the activity of other proteins that bind to filaments. This framework may be applicable to other proteins that are involved in the disassembly of filament networks.

The metabolic effects of fructose versus glucose on appetite and food intake are controversial. We show that ingestion of fructose versus glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The recent demographic growth happened in a heterogeneous way across the island, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case study for understanding the history of human colonization of the Indian Ocean. It also provides a reference for future studies on the island. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This work suggests that in-person interaction is not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of protein in all cells, and the ribosome is the primary machinery responsible for translating the information encoded in mRNA into protein. The ribosome is also responsible for modifying the mRNA sequence during translation, and this process is thought to be important for regulating protein synthesis. Here, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA sequence can have a profound impact on the ribosome’s ability to translate the mRNA. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This finding has implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in regulating protein synthesis. It also provides a new perspective on the role of the ribosome in mRNA modification. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and greater life satisfaction. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounders, and longitudinal analyses indicate that the feeling of being worthwhile is associated with positive changes in health and behavior over time. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study uses a quantitative approach to test the hypothesis that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving mammals toward a body size attractor in the water. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor in the water. The existence of this size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. The optimum size occurs at an intermediate value where thermoregulatory costs are low but feeding efficiency remains high. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. This study provides a quantitative test of the energetic constraints on the evolution of body size in mammals. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms.

The common cold is the most common viral infection in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a reduced antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C, the core body temperature, relative to 33 °C, the temperature found in the nasal cavity. This temperature-dependent induction of antiviral defense response correlates with higher levels of type I and type III IFNs and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This may explain the increased susceptibility of the nasal cavity to rhinovirus infection. (Show more)

The opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients. It is able to cause infections in a wide range of hosts, including humans, by modulating its virulence factors and biofilm formation. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili for sensing the environment, and that this sensing is important for the regulation of virulence. We demonstrate that type IV pili are involved in the sensing of surfaces, and that this sensing is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system. This system is similar to the chemotaxis system, and it is activated by the mechanical activity of type IV pili. Our results thus demonstrate that type IV pili are used by bacteria for sensing the environment, and that this sensing is important for the regulation of virulence. This study thus provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria can use their appendages for sensing the environment. This may be important for the development of new antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

The widespread use of pesticides in agriculture has been associated with a reduction in aquatic biodiversity. However, the magnitude of this impact has been difficult to quantify because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of the occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and their effects on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk due to the widespread occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. This risk is exacerbated by the use of newer-generation pesticides, which are more toxic than older ones. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study provides a comprehensive quantitative analysis of the impact of pesticides on global aquatic biodiversity. It is a must-read for anyone interested in the impact of pesticides on the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in wildlife. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. We found that SARS-CoV-2 RNA was detected in 33.2% of 283 retropharyngeal lymph node samples collected from deer in Iowa. The majority of deer-derived SARS-CoV-2 lineages were B.1.2 and B.1.311, which are also the predominant lineages in Iowa. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer and could be a source of human infection. A better understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2 in wildlife is critical to mitigate the risk of spillback into human populations. This study highlights the need for a “One Health” approach to study the pandemic. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the problems and challenges of building large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions. We find that the benefits of hydropower are overestimated and the costs underestimated. We also find that the environmental and social impacts of dams are not being adequately considered in the decision-making process. We propose that the industry needs to change its practices and that governments need to be more involved in the decision-making process.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. However, the earliest pathological changes in AD are attributed to Aβ plaques, which are only observed in the later stages of the disease. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain and that they are responsible for initiating the inflammatory response in AD. We demonstrate that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors, which are responsible for the activation of microglia, a key immune cell in the brain. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a new perspective on the role of the immune system in AD and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a comprehensive survey of the chicken bone assemblage from 234 archaeological sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. Our results show a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period, which is the earliest period known in which chickens were widely exploited for economic purposes. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of chicken domestication and its spread in the ancient world. (Show more)

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The folding of large proteins is particularly difficult to study because of the need to follow the folding process at high structural resolution. Here we use a combination of advanced mass-spectrometry methods to study the folding of the maltose binding protein, a large protein that folds in a well-characterized two-state manner. We find that the folding process is highly heterogeneous, with a fast collapse into a polyglobular state and a slower formation of a distinct folding intermediate. The intermediate is a native-like structure that is formed by segments that are distant in the sequence but adjacent in the native protein. The intermediate is a step on the folding pathway and is a structure that must be formed before the native state can be reached. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. They also provide a model for the folding of large proteins. The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on nascent RNA molecules. However, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we demonstrate that arginine, a major precursor of citrulline, is a key molecule in the immune dysfunction observed in sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function and decrease sepsis-induced immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the potential of arginine and citrulline as biomarkers of sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state with power-law statistics of its fluctuations. SOC systems are characterized by a nontrivial scaling behavior of their fluctuations, which is reflected in the scaling of their critical exponents. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the well-known sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models and their relation to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. This work explores the possibility of metallization of diamond, which would make it more robust and useful. We show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that the bandgap can be made direct. This work opens up new opportunities for diamond applications. It also provides a general framework for exploring the mechanical stability of materials. It is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based technologies.

The discovery of a large number of nodule-specific peptides in the model legume Medicago truncatula has led to the hypothesis that these peptides may have a role in plant immunity. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding their structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action against plant fungal pathogens. Here, we report the crystal structure of one of the most potent antifungal peptides, NCR044, and demonstrate that it is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also show that it binds to bioactive phosphoinositides and induces cell death in fungal germlings. This work provides a structural and mechanistic understanding of the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and opens up a new avenue for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the male–female interface is a site of molecular exchange. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We used proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that female-derived proteins become associated with sperm immediately after mating and that they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting blood clotting. VWF is deficient in the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The A1 domain in VWF binds to platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα), but the mechanism of this interaction is not known. We show that force application switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is consistent with the effects of mutations in VWD. The results explain the pathophysiology of VWD and suggest that the mechanism can be used to treat bleeding. This work provides a mechanism for understanding the effects of mutations in a large protein that is involved in many physiological and pathological processes. It also provides a method for studying the effects of forces on proteins. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the human virome and its impact on human health. The database includes over 45,000 unique virus taxa, with over 100 million viral sequences. It also provides a resource for studying the impact of viruses on human health, with over 2,200 virus–disease associations.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. We expect this technique to be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is inferred to be ∼15 °C, but the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past is unknown. We present a method for inferring past surface temperatures based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria and archaea. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Show more)

The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a ubiquitous ion channel that plays a critical role in many physiological processes. It is a unique channel in that it lacks a classic activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the BK channel’s unique properties and may help to understand its physiological roles. (Show more)

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, with an estimated 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2019. The Plasmodium parasite exploits the host cell’s biophysical properties to facilitate invasion, but the mechanisms by which the parasite achieves this are poorly understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host erythrocyte, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding challenges our current understanding of malaria invasion and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This may have implications for the development of antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. This work explores the possibility of metallization of diamond, which would make it more robust and useful. We show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that the bandgap can be made direct. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a new route to study the physics of elastic instability in solids. The findings are expected to advance our understanding of the mechanical properties of diamond and other materials. They also offer opportunities for applications in diamond-based devices. This work is expected to be of interest to researchers in materials science, physics, and engineering.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of low humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in host defense against influenza virus infection. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome, and suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. Our study also provides a rationale for the use of low humidity as a potential adjuvant to enhance influenza vaccination. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to unfold in a tree-like structure, with each word being processed sequentially. However, this assumption has not been tested directly. Here, we used intracranial recordings to show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity was consistent with a bottom-up parser that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language processing system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates cell fate decisions, cell proliferation, and cell survival. The pathway is regulated by two key components, the receptor Frizzled and the downstream component Axin. Axin is a large protein that can be regulated at two levels: transcriptionally and posttranscriptionally. We show that the two levels of regulation are functionally distinct and can be used to control the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the brainstem, the locus coeruleus and peri-LH region. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen fertilizers is a major driver of the global food production system. However, the use of nitrogen fertilizers is unsustainable, and the development of alternative nitrogen sources is urgently needed. Here, we demonstrate a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the nitrogenase activity of a diazotrophic bacterium is only activated when in contact with a specific host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, which could be used to sustainably deliver nitrogen to cereal crops. This system could also be extended to other crops and crops grown in symbiosis with other nitrogen-fixing bacteria. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the global food production system.

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate, and the causes of this deforestation are not well understood. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in it, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. The climate and health impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of a phaseout of fossil fuels, and the additional benefits of reducing other anthropogenic sources. We find that fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death, and a vaccine is needed for all countries. The current vaccines are effective, but their production costs are high, limiting their availability in low- and middle-income countries. We engineered a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is well-suited for large-volume production and exhibits enhanced immunogenicity. This engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD can be used in a variety of vaccine formats, and we anticipate that it will be useful in the global fight against COVID-19. The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric cancer of neural crest-derived tissues. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALs activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro. We further show that loss-of-function alleles of zebrafish ALKALs cause ectopic iridophore development, whereas gain-of-function alleles cause iridophore loss. These results provide in vivo evidence for the activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and their involvement in neural crest development. This study provides a link between ALKALs, ALK/LTK receptors, and neural crest development, which may have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma. This study also provides a model system for studying the role of ALK/LTK family receptors in other neural crest-derived tissues. (Show more)

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex and poorly understood process. We present the largest collection of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes to date, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results reveal a single lineage of plague that persisted over millennia without significant diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a unique perspective on the origins of plague and its impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 80% of the world’s grasslands and the conversion of 90% of the world’s cropland to intensive agriculture. This has resulted in massive losses of soil organic carbon (SOC) to the atmosphere. In this study, we show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions. These practices can be used to mitigate the effects of intensive agriculture on SOC and can be applied to existing cropland and grassland. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a pathway to climate-smart agriculture. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose a spillover risk to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for spillover and developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animal pollinators for the transfer of pollen between plants. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the reward’s quality, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the color of the red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this compound, and demonstrate that the compound is attractive to a vertebrate pollinator. This work provides evidence that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid with potential pharmaceutical applications. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions, but the genetic makeup of the population before the Roman Empire is largely unknown. Here we present the genome of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 500 and 700 AD. The genetic ancestry of these individuals is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but a subset of women exhibits a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. This heterogeneity is associated with a high frequency of artificial skull deformations, which were used to modify the appearance of women. Our results suggest that the genetic history of Europe is more complex than previously thought and that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, were investigated. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. Thus, MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The polymerase responsible for this replication, DNA polymerase δ (pol δ), is responsible for the stability of the Okazaki fragments and the sliding clamp, PCNA, is responsible for the stability of pol δ. We found that the pol δ holoenzyme is stable and maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. This behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, the replication of RNA molecules is difficult to achieve, and the synthesis of functional RNA molecules is even more challenging. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and even tRNA. This polymerase can replicate RNA molecules, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the polymerase can serve as the basis for the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the reconstruction of life in the laboratory. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new method for measuring neighborhood change that can be applied to other cities and other time-series datasets.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the stage of trial and error. The results of this study show that tocilizumab, which can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to produce antimicrobial isocyanide metabolites, but the BGC has not been shown to impact copper homeostasis. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC produces xanthocillin-derived isocyanides that bind copper and impact intracellular copper pools. We also show that xanthocillin-derived isocyanides have antimicrobial properties and can inhibit the activity of fungal and bacterial laccases. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the impact of copper on fungal interactions with other microbes. (Show more)

The formation of silica polymorphs in sedimentary rocks is a well-known process on Earth, but it is not well understood on Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and primary amorphous precipitates, and it is derived from a silicic volcanic source. The amorphous precipitates are derived from multiple aqueous solutions with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The presence of tridymite in sedimentary rocks at Gale crater, Mars, is a strong indication that the climate on Mars was warmer and wetter in the past.
