Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, which are the world’s most important carbon sinks. Despite their economic and ecological importance, the geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood. We use a large dataset of leaf-out dates and leaf-freezing temperatures to infer the resistance strategies of trees and to forecast the vulnerability of forests to frost damage under climate change. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Our results also provide a framework for studying the evolutionary impact of frost events on the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. Here we show that Th17 cells can directly induce colitis in a Stat4-dependent manner. Moreover, Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These findings suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. They also suggest that the development of Th17 cells may be a therapeutic target in inflammatory bowel disease. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Th17 cells in inflammatory bowel disease and suggests a potential therapeutic strategy. (Show more)

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in pathogen virulence and transmission. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the pathogen’s transmission. We demonstrate that iafgp alters the permeability of the gut barrier and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, which are critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. IAFGP thereby perturbs the tick microbiota, which influences the pathogen’s ability to colonize the vector. These findings elucidate the mechanisms by which a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vector and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is obscured by the limited known diversity of early branching members of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”). Here, we describe a basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. This study also provides new insights into the evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the modern avian body plan. (Show more)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand its behavior. One of the most difficult aspects of the climate system is the feedback between the stratosphere and troposphere. This feedback is important because it can amplify small changes in the climate system. We show that the stratospheric water vapor feedback is significant, and that it is important to understand the behavior of the climate system.

Vertebrates have evolved a variety of color changes to avoid predation and camouflage. One such color change is the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood of vertebrates. This study shows that the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins, are most similar to human antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and its diverse functions. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and the hypoxic tumor microenvironment is a major driver of cancer progression. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the proportion of breast cancer cells that are cancer stem cells (BCSCs). BCSCs are responsible for initiating metastasis and relapse, and are resistant to chemotherapy. Thus, targeting ALKBH5 may be a strategy for treating breast cancer.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This study provides a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The results suggest that the parchment of the earliest pocket Bibles was not made from the skin of fetal calves or sheep, as has been assumed, but rather from the skins of maturing animals of several species. This study also demonstrates the utility of noninvasive methods in codicology. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. Understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics depends on an accurate and precise age model. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of immune complexes in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a heterogeneous disease, and the exact pathogenesis is still unknown. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating virus, and it is hypothesized to increase infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the D614G and G614 spikes and show that the G614 spike is more open and flexible, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results support the hypothesis that the D614G mutation increases infectivity. They also provide a structural basis for the development of vaccines and therapeutics that target the more infectious G614 mutant. (Show more)

We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, which would increase the Black−White life expectancy gap to over 5 y. These projections imply that the pandemic has exacerbated the structural inequalities that have led to the Black−White life expectancy gap, which has been reduced by only 1.5 y since 2006. Our findings highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that have led to the disproportionate burden of COVID-19 and the need to address the social determinants of health.

The chemical properties of atoms are fundamental to chemistry, and they are also of great interest in condensed matter physics. In this work, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms, and that these changes can be predicted by a simple model. This model can be used to predict the behavior of chemical properties under pressure, and it can also be used to predict the behavior of chemical properties under other conditions, such as temperature. This work is of interest to chemists and physicists alike.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but this is not the case everywhere. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can have a strong influence on fire regimes, and that these can have a significant impact on the global carbon cycle. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the role of human ignitions and fire suppression in shaping the future of fire regimes. This will be critical for understanding the potential impacts of climate change on fire regimes and the carbon cycle.

The symbiotic associations that animals form with microbes are among the most important interactions in nature. These associations are often highly specific, with only one or a few microbes colonizing a host for extended periods. The mechanisms that regulate the activities of these microbes are poorly understood. Here, we show that the symbiotic association between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is regulated by the host’s provision of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is provided only at night, when the squid’s symbiotic organ is at its most metabolically active. We propose that this glycan is the only nutrient required for the metabolic activity of the symbionts, which in turn modulates the host’s oxygen supply to the organ, thereby regulating the symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiotic interactions. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We can infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics and their prevalence in texts about female and male victims. Our method can be extended to other types of data, such as images.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results suggest that the Black Death was not caused by a single introduction of Y. pestis, but rather by multiple introductions, each of which was followed by a delay of 15 y before the disease became established in Europe

Asteroids are a common species of the Northeast Pacific Ocean, and populations of at least 20 species have recently experienced an extensive outbreak of sea-star wasting disease. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animal, and the cause of the disease has been unknown. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus, and that the virus is transmitted by the starfish Asterias rubens. The virus is likely to be the causative agent of the disease, and our findings have important implications for the management of this important marine ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor, with a high mortality rate. The identification of AML stem cells is of great importance for the development of more efficient therapies. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor on AML stem cells can efficiently eradicate AML in xenograft models. We also show that the antibodies can induce antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and block IL-1 signaling, which is important for the growth of AML cells. These results provide evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, revealing a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The recent demographic growth happened in a heterogeneous way across the island, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case study for understanding the history of human colonization of the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of currently available vaccines and treatments. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning algorithm to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We applied this algorithm to a human antibody, P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our algorithm identified CDR changes that improved the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work provides a promising approach for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can support memory, but that changes in the intrinsic excitability of neurons are more efficient. We demonstrate that these adaptive changes in neuronal excitability can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This work highlights the need for more long-term, multisite studies to better understand the response of soil respiration to warming. (Show more)

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging to model, as it involves the loss of a major metabolic pathway and the acquisition of a new lifestyle. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This evolutionary trajectory may be relevant to other transitions from autotrophy to heterotrophy. This work also provides a framework for the study of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes. The contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought has been estimated through observations and climate models. However, model adequacy and insufficient horizontal resolution make it difficult to precisely quantify the changing likelihood of extreme droughts, given the small regional scale. Here, we use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear SSA rainfall deficits in past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test,” has implications for the history of the Earth and for the origin of quasicrystals. The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS). The role of neuroinflammation in MS is still controversial, and the mechanisms of neuroinflammation in MS are poorly understood. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of glial ASK1 in neuroinflammation. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also extremely warm. This finding is important because the probability of warm–dry conditions is very high in the near future, and because the 2012–2014 drought has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. Our results also suggest that the probability of drought years will continue to increase in the future, and that this increase will be exacerbated by continued global warming. Thus, the 2012–2014 drought is a harbinger of what is to come.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad phenotypic spectrum. The etiology of ASD is so complicated that it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in ASD and may facilitate the development of new treatments for ASD. (Show more)

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that this is indeed the case, and that the magnitude of the negativity bias varies considerably across individuals. This work thus helps account for the prevalence of negative news content, and also highlights the potential for more positive content to be more widely consumed.

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO(2)) channel is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the SO(2) channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1, associated with Stormorken syndrome, and show that these mutations result in constitutive activation of the SO(2) channel. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO(2) channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO(2) channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of synaptic vesicles with the cell body. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of disease progression. The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immunologically privileged, which is thought to protect them from infectious diseases. However, the immunosuppressant protein (MTX) identified in this study is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats and is a potent immunomodulator that can facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to treat viral infections. This study also provides a potential explanation for the origin of MTX and the evolution of LTA4H in bats. The findings of this study may also help to understand the pathogenesis of viral infections in bats and the evolution of viral infections in bats. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a number of metabolic vulnerabilities that can be exploited therapeutically. One such vulnerability is the deficiency of one-carbon units, which are essential for cell growth. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. Here we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the cancer cell-line screen that led to the discovery of the inhibitor also identified a glycine importer, which is defective in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. This work also provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the coaggregating proteins are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners, suggesting that they are metastable in motor neurons. Thus, the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS results from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases in which proteins are prone to aggregation. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal band structures are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be extended to 3D geometries to enable many-body physics with cold atoms in optical lattices. This work opens up a new platform for many-body physics with cold atoms. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. These plants are known from the Cretaceous period, which is the last period of the Mesozoic era and the last time that the Earth was warm enough for plants to colonize the land. The study of Montsechia, a Cretaceous aquatic angiosperm, is presented here. Montsechia is an important fossil plant because it is the oldest known aquatic angiosperm. It is also an important fossil plant because it is the type specimen of a genus that was previously poorly understood. The study of Montsechia raises questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade and the role of aquatic habitats in the early evolution of the angiosperms. The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. They also provide a unique opportunity to study the evolution of human populations in the past. (Show more)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. The rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and the acceleration is being driven by the thermal expansion of the oceans and the melting of glaciers and ice sheets. The acceleration is not uniform, however, and we find that the acceleration is not uniform, but varies by ocean basin. The acceleration is greatest in the Arctic Ocean, where it is 0.31 ± 0.12 mm/y2, and least in the Southern Ocean, where it is 0.09 ± 0.04 mm/y2. The acceleration is also not uniform in time, with the acceleration being greatest in the 2000s and least in the 1990s.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase is more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader trend of erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The ability to characterize the structure of enzyme intermediates in solution and in crystals is a powerful tool for understanding enzyme mechanism. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to understand the reaction pathway of a defining enzyme intermediate. This approach provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the intermediate, including the location of the protonation states of ionizable sites, the tautomeric equilibrium of the amino group, and the location of crystallographic waters within the active site. The detailed picture of the intermediate structure and dynamics provides insight into the reaction pathway, which is critical for understanding the mechanism of the enzyme. This approach can be extended to other enzyme intermediates, providing a powerful tool for mechanistic enzymology. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe emerging coronavirus infection that causes a high mortality rate. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral that has shown promising activity against SARS-CoV, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment initiated early after infection provided a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing outbreak. The availability of effective antiviral treatments is critical to reduce the impact of emerging infectious diseases.

The symbiotic associations that animals form with microbes are among the most important interactions in nature. These associations are often highly specific, with only one or a few microbes colonizing a host for extended periods. The mechanisms that regulate the activities of these microbes are poorly understood. Here, we show that the symbiotic association between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is regulated by the host’s provision of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is provided just before dusk, when the squid’s symbiotic organ is at its most stable, and is catabolized by the symbiont only at night, when the organ is producing light. This glycan-dependent regulation of the symbiont population and organ function may be a general mechanism for regulating the activities of specific microbes in the host’s epithelium. (Show more)

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. We tested whether teachers (n = 39) could be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline—to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. We found that teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions. Moreover, teachers’ mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention. This study has implications for the future of school discipline.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages during virus-producing cell secretion. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The results also suggest that the first cleavages are important for virus trafficking into endosomes, where the more rigid uncleaved MERS viruses are less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lack sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. The food system is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and is a leading cause of biodiversity loss and water pollution. The food choices of the world’s population are a key driver of these environmental impacts. In high-income countries, the majority of people are not eating a sustainable diet. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a significant impact on meal selection. This approach could be easily implemented in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces. It could also be used to target specific groups, such as those who are vegetarian or vegan, or those who are not eating enough fruit and vegetables. This approach could therefore be a powerful tool for improving population health and environmental sustainability.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a distinct surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We also find that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by oncogenes, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This study provides a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggests possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We also find that vote-by-mail does not appear to increase the likelihood of voter fraud. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of vaccines and therapeutics. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface that may mediate immune suppression. This work provides a molecular understanding of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2, which may be exploited for the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. It arises when we have a large dataset and wish to find associations in it. The fact that we have cherry-picked the dataset means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding and controlling the error rates of statistical methods in big data.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells is still a challenge. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the generation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. ETV2-mediated induction of ETVCs (ETVECs) is independent of hematopoietic development factors, and ETV2-induced ETVCs can form mature vascular networks in vivo. These findings provide a promising approach for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study also provides a potential strategy for the generation of vascular networks for the regeneration of damaged organs. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are critical for the development of the zebrafish eye and iridophore pigmentation. Here, we show that the zebrafish augmentor genes encode ligands for Ltk and that these ligands are essential for iridophore patterning in the eye and pigmentation of the body. Our results establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a unique model system to explore the function of orphan RTKs and their ligands in vivo. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in T2D has been extensively studied, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in peripheral tissues and β-cells beneficially ameliorated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance, whereas STING-βKO impaired insulin secretion in β-cells. These findings suggest that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Moreover, STING deficiency in β-cells decreased nuclear localization of Pax6, a transcription factor that is required for insulin gene expression. These data establish a pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a better understanding of the role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and may provide a potential target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

The role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis has been demonstrated. However, the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. Here, we found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. In addition, treatment with statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibited YAP/TAZ activities to diminish the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-started wildfires relative to lightning-started wildfires. We find that human-started wildfires have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that the human-started fire season is three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season. These findings highlight the importance of reducing the risk of human-started wildfires to reduce the economic and ecological costs of wildfire.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new method for monitoring the physical appearance of neighborhoods and for studying the spatial dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated dTRPγ ion channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents in Drosophila melanogaster. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. While the symptoms of bleaching have been extensively characterized, the underlying causes remain largely unknown. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and identifies a potential therapeutic target. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. We found that treatment of breast cancer cells with chemotherapy increased the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1, which in turn enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. We also found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is controversial, with some studies suggesting that it began as early as 19.5 ka, whereas others argue that it did not begin until 17.7 ka. We show that the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series that occurred exactly at the start of the period of accelerated deglaciation. The volcanic eruptions are associated with stratospheric ozone depletion, which likely contributed to the changes in climate and the rate of deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can be used to link climate change to specific events in the Earth system. It also provides a new perspective on the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the climate system. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable structure of LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 is responsible for the high capacity and low operating potential. The hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a previously unknown form of regeneration in the adult Caenorhabditis elegans nervous system, which is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is independent of the DLK-1/DLK signaling pathway. This DLK-independent regeneration is linked to a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These connections suggest that ectopic regeneration represents a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between DLK-independent regeneration and lesion conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Recombination is a fundamental process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genomic stability. In eukaryotes, it is catalyzed by a family of proteins called recombinases. Recombinases are thought to initiate recombination at specific sites, which are then propagated by a process of gene conversion. Here, we describe the spatial pattern of recombination initiation in the flowering plant Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination initiation is polarized within genes, and that the initiation sites are enriched for positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9 binding sites. These results suggest that recombination initiation in eukaryotes may be a conserved eukaryotic process. (Show more)

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which fluctuations in functional connectivity are used to identify and characterize functional networks. However, the majority of these fluctuations are not related to neuronal activity, but rather to physiological noise. The identification of the remaining fluctuations, which are related to neuronal activity, is a major challenge in the field. Here, we used a nonfluctuating signal, related to total brain activity, to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects was topologically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. This study provides a direct link between the metabolic and functional organization of the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for efficient translation. We now show that the yeast cell cycle regulator CDC20 is encoded on a 5′ NAD+ RNA. This is the first example of a 5′ NAD+ RNA in eukaryotes, and raises the possibility that this modification could modulate mRNA stability and translation.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control could prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of this therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the DCCT, supporting an epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory observed in the long-term follow-up of the DCCT.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective targeted therapies. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells promotes autophagy, inhibits mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin signaling, and sensitizes cells to chemotherapy. These findings uncover a role of FSIP1 in drug sensitivity and may aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The mechanisms underlying the development of alcohol dependence are not fully understood, but the brain has traditionally been considered the main target. Recently, the existence of a gut–brain axis has been suggested, which may explain the complex and multifactorial nature of this disorder. In the present study, we found that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disorder. Moreover, we found that the gut microbiota is altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which contribute to the overall aroma and flavor. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known, and the contribution of nitrogenous volatiles to the overall flavor is unknown. Here we report the discovery of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and opens the door to the development of improved cultivars. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we use high-throughput experiments to investigate how changes in temperature affect the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that changes in temperature systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures departed from ambient conditions the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increased, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of conservation and management strategies, as well as for the assessment of the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record from freely moving mice in an open field, and we found that grid cells, which are essential for place learning, are strongly organized in space and are anatomically distinct from other neurons in MEC. These findings provide a framework for understanding the organization of MEC and its functional modules in the intact brain. They also provide a platform for future studies of the neural basis of navigation. This work is expected to advance our understanding of the neural basis of spatial cognition. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and endogenous signals. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene, which is known to be involved in flowering in plants, is also involved in flowering of the parasitic dodder Cuscuta australis. We show that FT is able to induce flowering of dodder, and that FT is able to move from the host plant to the dodder. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model system for studying the function of FTs in flowering. (Show more)

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized specialized subsystem within the nigrostriatal system that is formed by striosomes, dopamine-containing dendrites, and striatonigral fibers. We show that striosomes project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway and that they form bouquet-like arborizations within which striosomal fibers are tightly intertwined with dopamine-containing dendrites and with other neurons and glia. These findings suggest that striosomes are involved in the formation of specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent a critical component of the nigro–striato–nigral loop that is affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. This study provides a unique view of the functional organization of the dopamine system in health and disease. It also provides a model for the study of other specialized subsystems

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people “click”? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart, and its rate is largely determined by the number of cells that are able to generate action potentials. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs), which are responsible for the generation of action potentials. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is selectively expressed in SANCs and is required for the generation of action potentials in these cells. We also show that STIM1 regulates the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry and the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger in SANCs, thereby influencing the electrical activity of the SAN. These findings reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the regulation of SAN function. (Show more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by priming of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect rice from insect attack. This study also provides a new paradigm for understanding the role of silicon in plant physiology. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of ether lipids in murine macrophages. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is up-regulated by IFN-γ/lipopolysaccharide, which is a major stimulus of macrophages, and that this activity is involved in the regulation of the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and suggest that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is involved in the regulation of macrophage activation. These findings may have implications for the treatment of phenylketonuria. (Show more)

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The neural basis of this ability is still not fully understood. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during normal activity. We show that these changes in excitability can be used to store information in the firing rate of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. Our results provide a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. They also suggest that memory is a fundamental property of the brain that can be used to understand the neural basis of language processing.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical challenge for the development of plant-based therapeutics. Herein, we demonstrate the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up a new avenue for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and the development of plant-based therapeutics. This work also provides a platform for the development of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to other organisms. (Show more)

Nutrient pollution from small tributaries is a major concern for large lakes, but it has been largely overlooked in the United States. We show that nutrient inputs from small tributaries are disproportionately high in coastal areas, where they can fuel algal blooms. We also show that small tributaries are more likely to deliver nutrients in a dissolved form, which is more bioavailable to algae. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, which are often overlooked in current efforts. This could help reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combinations of cosmological parameters that are required to explain the observed cosmic microwave background radiation are also the ones that lead to the fine-tuned extremization of the cosmological constant.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in cortical microcircuitry can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. Understanding the history of abrupt warming events is therefore of utmost importance. Here, we present a detailed reconstruction of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the warming was accompanied by a pronounced perturbation of the carbon cycle, which was likely driven by an increase in nutrient supply. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduces tropical forest loss in Indonesia, the world’s largest producer and consumer of palm oil. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification has failed to reduce deforestation in Indonesia, and that certification may be contributing to the conversion of forests to oil palm. We argue that broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations are necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our findings highlight the need for more rigorous evaluation of the effectiveness of certification schemes. (Show more)

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 14 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major focus of evolutionary biology. In many species, sex determination is binary, with two sexes and two sexes only. However, in many other species, sex determination is polygenic, with multiple alleles segregating within a single species, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles, one of which determines female sex, interact to produce four possible sexes. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the introgression of a newly acquired sex determiner can create additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct but related insults: accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) and photodamage. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that Fe levels impact the retina in two ways: (i) increased Fe levels promote the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids, and (ii) decreased Fe levels promote the oxidation of A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that Fe chelation may be a useful strategy for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. This interpretation is supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreases the oxidation of A2E in the presence of light and reduces cell death in cell-based experiments.
